PEDESTRIAN PAVEMENT IN OLD
KALLANG AIRPORT ESTATE
(Repairs to damage)


    3. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he has any plans to repair the damaged roadside pedestrian pavement in the Old Kallang Airport Estate and, if so, when.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Sir, action has already been initiated by the Public Works Department to repair the badly damaged pedestrian pavement in the Old Kallang Airport Estate, and work is in progress.

(Widening)


    4. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law and National Development why that portion of Upper Serangoon Road in front of the petrol kiosk, opposite Flower Road, has not yet been widened; and if he will take steps for the widening of that portion of the Road to allow the smooth flow of vehicular traffic.

Column: 1252

PUNGGOL ROAD
(Widening and surfacing)


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law and National Development, in view of the increase in vehicular traffic and accidents along Punggol Road up to Punggol Point, if he will consider the widening and resurfacing of the Road.

Barker): Sir, the existing 24 feet wide carriageway of Punggol Road is considered adequate to cater for the present volume of vehicular traffic. However, as development around Punggol Point is increasing, a survey is now being made in respect of the widening of Punggol Road. Subject to securing the necessary approval of funds, work for the widening of the road can be carried out next year. Meanwhile every effort will be made to keep the road in a satisfactory condition.

PEDESTRIAN OVERHEAD BRIDGE OR CROSSING
AT JALAN BAHAGIA
(Construction)


    10. Dr Augustine H. H. Tan asked the Minister for Law and National Development, in view of the heavy traffic along Jalan Bahagia and the large numbers of children crossing the road daily, if he will consider providing (i) an overhead pedestrian bridge; or (ii) a traffic-light-controlled pedestrian crossing.

PEDESTRIAN OVERHEAD BRIDGE

NEAR KANDANG KERBAU MARKET
(Construction)

However, the police consider it undesirable to erect an overhead bridge leading into the compound of a police station.

SCHOLARSHIPS AND BURSARIES FOR
MEMBERS OF ASSOCIATIONS
(Income tax exemption on contributions to associations' funds)


    13. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Finance if consideration will be given to income tax exemption in respect of contributions to funds which are set up by registered associations to provide for scholarships or bursaries for members of the associations and their families.

    The Minister of State for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Income Tax Ordinance provides exemption from income tax on contributions to funds for the provision of scholarships in a university or an educational

Column: 1257

institution which is not operated as a profit-making body. This relief is provided under paragraph (c) (vi) of section 37 (2) of the Income Tax Ordinance.

    In considering applications, my Ministry would regard as desirable criteria to qualify for such reliefs that the funds be properly constituted and that the scholarships and bursaries be open to all members of the public, irrespective of their race and religion. My Ministry would find it more difficult to allow the same privilege to registered associations which restrict their scholarships and bursaries to members of the associations and their families only, as this can easily lead to abuse. If such exemption is allowed, it would not require much imagination for people to take advantage of it to avoid payment of income tax by forming associations of small groups to pay for the education of their children.

CEMENT
(Steps to overcome shortage)


    14. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Finance if he will make a statement on the recent shortage of cement in Singapore, the reasons therefor and the steps he proposes to take to overcome it.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry is not aware of any real shortage of cement recently, although there have been fears expressed of such a shortage. Any threat to the smooth tempo of building construction activity is, however, the concern of my Ministry which has, therefore, investigated this matter. The alarm appears to have been created because a small proportion of clinker imports did not meet the required specifications for cement manufacture. The production of acceptable cement in one of the factories consequently fell, and this created an unnecessary panic. However, the position of clinker supplies in Singapore is quite healthy at the moment, and the

Column: 1258

three manufacturers within the industry are co-operating with one another to maintain a production level in line with the demand.

    It may be of interest to Members to know that the production capacity for manufacture of cement is at present one million tons per year, and this is expected to increase to 1.2 million tons by October 1971. The demand for cement in the year 1971 is expected to be in the region of about 850,000 tons, averaging 71,000 tons a month, or 2,400 tons per day. From the information provided by the industry, the manufacturers are at present supplying between 2,300 and 2,600 tons a day. This is sufficient to meet the local demand.

    However, our cement industry is dependent on imported clinker, and any short supply of clinker could well affect the supply position in the cement industry. Because of this, my Ministry is keeping a constant review of the position of clinker stocks. Should we find that the clinker stocks are such as to threaten cement supplies, we shall not hesitate to take immediate action to allow imports into Singapore duty free to meet the local demand. It is very unlikely that this will be necessary.

    It may be mentioned that my Ministry has established a consultative committee with representatives from manufacturers and the Contractors' Association to review the position of cement from time to time.

1ST APRIL, 1971, TO 31ST MARCH, 1972

2.47 p.m.

    The Chairman: Before we proceed to consider the business of the Committee, may I, in the light of certain remarks made yesterday in the Committee of Supply, refer hon. Members to two Standing Orders. The first concerns the

use of languages in Parliament, that is Standing Order 43, which provides that an hon. Member may speak either in Malay, Mandarin, Tamil or English, as it is permitted by Article 37 of the Constitution.

    The second Standing Order is paragraph (2) of Standing Order 47 which provides, inter alia, that reference shall not be made to any matter which is sub judice. I would urge hon. Members to exercise caution in referring to any matter which is before a court of law awaiting adjudication. Thank you.

    I come now to the Development Estimates of Expenditure for Singapore for the financial year 1st April, 1971, to 31st March. 1972, contained in Paper Cmd. 4 of 1971. I shall take the total for each head of expenditure as it appears in the last column of the Summary of Estimated Expenditure on pages 5 and 6 of the Paper.

    I shall deal first with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement.

    Head 01 -

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker. Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 01 be reduced by $10 in respect of item 001 of subhead 101.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sure that everybody will be very glad to note that an initial sum of $2 million has been set aside for the construction of the proposed subordinate court building at Havelock Road. I wonder if the Minister can give us additional information about the architectural and other features of the proposed building: that is information additional to what has already been given in the Memorandum on the Development Estimates, as well as from any other pronouncements recently made.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I think that justice should be meted out in circumstances of proper appearance of physical dignity, and that the law should be administered under conditions that reflect the progress that we see in other aspects of

Column: 1260

Singapore life. Currently, without going too much into tedious details, an atmosphere of physical gloom, congestion and dilapidation hangs over our subordinate courts. I had an opportunity recently to take a look at them and it was quite a depressing experience.

    I am sure that in the administration of the law we want to get the maximum public co-operation. I would hope that after this proposed new building is completed, there will be appropriate space and amenities for witnesses and the general public. Mr Speaker, Sir, every year thousands of people, including witnesses, have contacts with the courts. What sort of impression do these people get if the conditions they experience are such as they are experiencing now?

    Finally. I note with some anxiety that the Memorandum on the Development Estimates states that work may start in mid-year. I would urge that every effort be made to implement the decision that is involved in the vote on which I am speaking.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I say at the outset that I agree with the views expressed by the Member for Katong. The subordinate courts were already in a bad way when I used to practise in them eight years ago. They must have become worse since then. Hence, the new court building.

    The provision of $2 million against subhead 101 is required to meet the cost of construction works for the first year only. The whole project is estimated to take about 31 months to complete, from the date of obtaining vacant possession of the site. Reference to this subject was made in January 1971. Actual piling work is scheduled to commence next month, but there have been delays in site clearance, and the present Havelock Road, which forms part of the site, cannot be closed until the alternative proposed major road system in that area is implemented.

    The Member will be pleased to know that the subordinate court complex will be the first of its kind in this part of the

Science Centre is not responsible for science research. It is an organisation responsible for some kind of a museum. I hope the Member for Sembawang will be able to distinguish between the kinds of work to be undertaken. I hope that the Science Centre will be completed by 1974 or 1975.

    (*The same amendment also stood in the name of Dr Augustine Tan.)

    Sir, the University of Singapore is considered to be one of the best institutions of higher learning. It is responsible for the training of professionals required for the country. Therefore, the expenditure to be voted for is justified.

    However, I wish to ask the Minister the following questions:

    Firstly, when will the construction of the building be completed?

    Secondly, how will the furniture and equipment and land be acquired with $10 under each item? Are there any plans to proceed with the purchase of furniture and equipment and the acquisition of land?

    Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, in addition to the queries of the Member for Sembawang, may I ask the Minister for Science and Technology the following questions:

    Firstly, in regard to the sports complex in the new University site, may I know whether a swimming pool is envisaged?

    Secondly, I would like to ask the Minister whether it is proposed to provide housing of some kind for the University staff at the new site.

    Thirdly, is it proposed to air-condition all the offices and lecture halls at the new campus?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will reply in a language which will be familiar to both Members who have asked me the questions. First of all, to answer the Member for Sembawang on the question of the $l0 vote. This signifies that the Ministry has staked a claim for furniture and equipment and for land. Of course, you cannot buy a table these days for $10 unless it is a second hand table. But the $10 vote is to indicate that in future, if it is necessary for the University to acquire equipment, a submission will be made to the Ministry of Finance.

    In the case of land, nothing has been settled. I have no idea at all how the University is going to pay for the acquisition of land at Kent Ridge. This is a problem which is beyond the University, and it has to be settled between the Bases Economic Conversion Department, representing the Singapore Government, and the British Services.

    To date, what has happened is this. We have submitted five papers providing the data which have been asked for by the World Bank. The World Bank has sent officers periodically to discuss with the University Development Unit the progress that is being made in planning. We are now waiting for an appraisal team to come out from Washington so that studies can be further elaborated if necessary, and the World Bank can make a final decision on how much of the application which we have made will be supported.

    With regard to the question of the sports complex which has been raised by the Member for Whampoa, I would just like to point out that it is very far distant in planning. We have no immediate plans for it, although the intention, of course, is to devote a part

Column: 1265

of the land to sports activities which will include facilities for students and staff who wish to play soccer, rugger, hockey, and cricket if necessary. But we have to make optimum use of existing facilities. There is already in existence a sports complex about 300 yards north of Kent Ridge, next door to the St. John's International School and the Polytechnic which will be sited at Dover Road. This sports complex has been built at very heavy cost. Several claims have been made for the sports complex which includes a swimming pool, a pavilion and changing rooms. I believe the Ministry of Social Affairs and the Ministry of Education are also making a claim. But until a final decision has been made, I cannot guarantee that we need to plan for another swimming pool, because I believe that whatever facilities are available in that area should also be made available to the whole community and not to the students only.

    As for University staff housing, I am told that there are existing, as of this moment in Kent Ridge, houses which are now being occupied by officers in the British Army. Of this number, about 55 will have to be demolished in order to make way for Phase One of the development project. So there will be 45 houses left which can be used to house the University staff. There are also houses in Medway and Sussex Parks which are adjacent to Kent Ridge. Again I have made a bid for them on behalf of the University and the Polytechnic as well, so that we can utilise them for teachers who wish to teach at the University or the Polytechnic. But no final decision can be made on the utilisation of these houses because, excepting those at Kent Ridge, real estate problems have to be solved between the Singapore Government and the British, Australian and New Zealand Governments which are proposing to place a token force in Singapore. I believe there is at the moment an examination of the needs of this token force which will be in Singapore. But our intention is that, as far as possible,

Column: 1266

the locality in Pasir Panjang should be made available for economic and educational development.

    However, where possible and where land is available, it will be the intention of the University to build flats for housing its staff, and similarly I have also suggested to the Polytechnic that when it moves over to Dover Road, flats ought to be built to house its staff. In this way, we can bring the staff nearer to the campus. These two problems are being looked after.

    As for air-conditioning, I am more concerned with the annual maintenance costs and the public utility charges which the University will have to pay, than with the capital expenditure which will be incurred by installing air-conditioning plants. I believe that the annual operating cost of air-conditioning is $1.10 per square foot per annum. The Faculty for Engineering alone is asking for a total floor area of 393,750 square feet. But of this area, a total of 315,000 square feet is to be air-conditioned, because laboratories which contain sensitive equipment will have to be air-conditioned and it is the intention to provide air-conditioned rooms in the lecture theatres as well as in seminar rooms and staff rooms. The annual operating cost of air-conditioning this space alone for the Engineering Faculty is $346,500. If you extrapolate the cost of maintaining air-conditioning for all other faculties - Science, Architecture, Business Administration and ultimately the Teaching Hospital - you can imagine how much the annual recurrent costs of upkeeping the University will be. Therefore, we have to be very careful that we do not air-condition every part of the University. The workshops and the corridors are decidedly not going to be air-conditioned. The whole campus complex is being planned on a modular basis so that, where necessary, air conditioning can be installed as and when members of the staff feel fit. And when it is not necessary, the air-conditioning can also be turned off. This is uppermost in our minds. It is not just the capital expenditure which is required to put up the University at

Column: 1267

Kent Ridge but the annual recurrent costs as well. I hope I have answered all the questions which have been raised by the Members for Sembawang and Whampoa.
